{{Infobox scientist |name = Genichi Taguchi |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1924|1|1|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Tokamachi, Niigata|Tokamachi]], [[Japan]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2012|6|2|1924|1|1|mf=y}} |death_place = Japan |residence = |citizenship = Japan |nationality = |ethnicity = |fields = [[engineering]], [[statistics]] |workplaces = [[Aoyama Gakuin University]] |alma_mater = [[Gunma University|Kiryu Technical College]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = [[Taguchi methods]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = [[Matosaburo Masuyama]] |influenced = |awards = [[Medals of Honour (Japan)#Blue ribbon|Indigo Ribbon]], [[Shewhart Medal]]
[[Automotive Hall of Fame]] |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} {{nihongo|'''Genichi Taguchi'''|田口 玄一|Taguchi Gen'ichi}} (January 1, 1924 – June 2, 2012) was an [[engineer]] and [[statistician]].{{cite web |url=http://www.asiusa.com/thought-leadership/news-and-events/167-death-of-dr-taguchi |title=ASI Mourns the Loss of Dr. Genichi Taguchi |publisher=Asiusa.com |date=2012-03-28 |accessdate=2012-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019015145/http://www.asiusa.com/thought-leadership/news-and-events/167-death-of-dr-taguchi |archivedate=2012-10-19 |df= }} From the 1950s onwards, Taguchi developed a methodology for applying [[statistics]] to improve the quality of manufactured goods. [[Taguchi methods]] have been controversial among some conventional Western statisticians,{{cite book |last=Wadsworth |first=Harrison M. |title=Handbook of statistical methods for engineers and scientists |edition=2nd |year=1997 |location=New York |publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional}}{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Gerald F. |title=Quality problem solving |year=1998 |publisher=American Society for Quality |pages=250?251}} but others have accepted many of the concepts introduced by him as valid extensions to the body of knowledge. ==Biography== Taguchi was born and raised in the textile town of [[Tokamachi, Niigata|Tokamachi]], in [[Niigata prefecture]]. He initially studied textile [[engineering]] at [[Gunma University|Kiryu Technical College]] with the intention of entering the family [[kimono]] business.{{cite web |title=Genichi Taguchi |url=http://www.asq.org/about-asq/who-we-are/bio_taguchi.html |publisher=American Society for Quality}} However, with the escalation of [[World War II]] in 1942, he was drafted into the Astronomical Department of the Navigation Institute of the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]]. After the war, in 1948 he joined the [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Public Health and Welfare]], where he came under the influence of eminent [[statistician]] [[Matosaburo Masuyama]], who kindled his interest in the [[design of experiments]]. He also worked at the [[Institute of Statistical Mathematics]] during this time, and supported experimental work on the production of [[penicillin]] at [[Morinaga Pharmaceuticals]], a [[Morinaga & Company|Morinaga Seika]] company. In 1950, he joined the Electrical Communications Laboratory (ECL) of the [[Nippon Telegraph and Telephone]] Corporation just as statistical quality control was beginning to become popular in [[Japan]], under the influence of [[W. Edwards Deming]] and the [[Japanese Union of Scientists and Engineers]]. ECL was engaged in a rivalry with [[Bell Labs]] to develop cross bar and telephone switching systems, and Taguchi spent his twelve years there in developing methods for enhancing quality and reliability. Even at this point, he was beginning to consult widely in Japanese industry, with [[Toyota]] being an early adopter of his ideas. During the 1950s, he collaborated widely and in 1954-1955 was visiting professor at the [[Indian Statistical Institute]], where he worked with [[C. R. Rao]], [[Ronald Fisher]] and [[Walter A. Shewhart]].{{cite book |last=Jayaswal |first=Bijay K. |author2=Peter C. Patton |title=Design for Trustworthy Software: Tools, Techniques, and Methodology of Developing Robust Software |year=2006 |publisher=Prentice Hall |page=44}} While working at the SQC Unit of ISI, he was introduced to the [[orthogonal array testing|orthogonal arrays]] invented by C. R. Rao - a topic which was to be instrumental in enabling him to develop the foundation blocks of what is now known as Taguchi methods. On completing his doctorate at [[Kyushu University]] in 1962,{{cite journal |last=Taguchi |first=Genichi |title=Quality engineering (Taguchi methods) for the development of electronic circuit technology |journal=IEEE Transactions on Reliability |publisher=IEEE Reliability Society |volume=44 |issue=2 |date=June 1995 |pages=225?229 |issn=0018-9529 |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?tp=&arnumber=387375&isnumber=8781 |doi=10.1109/24.387375}}{{Cite book|title=Studies on mathematical statistics for quality control|author=Gen'ichi TAGUCHI|publisher=Kushu University|date=March 1962|series=Doctoral thesis|url=http://iss.ndl.go.jp/books/R100000002-I000007814567-00}} he left ECL, though he maintained a consulting relationship. In the same year he visited [[Princeton University]] under the sponsorship of [[John Tukey]], who arranged a spell at [[Bell Labs]], his old ECL rivals. In 1964 he became professor of [[engineering]] at [[Aoyama Gakuin University]], [[Tokyo]]. In 1966 he began a collaboration with [[Yuin Wu]], who later emigrated to the [[United States|U.S.]] and, in 1980, invited Taguchi to lecture. During his visit there, Taguchi himself financed a return to [[Bell Labs]], where his initial teaching had made little enduring impact. This second visit began a collaboration with [[Madhav Phadke]] and a growing enthusiasm for his methodology in [[Bell Labs]] and elsewhere, including [[Ford Motor Company]], [[Boeing]], [[Xerox]] and [[ITT Corporation|ITT]]. Since 1982, Genichi Taguchi has been an advisor to the [[Japanese Standards Institute]] and executive director of the American Supplier Institute, an international consulting organisation.{{cite web |title=About ASI |url=http://www.amsup.com/about.htm |publisher=American Supplier Institute |accessdate=2009-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402001648/http://www.amsup.com/about.htm |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }} His concepts pertaining to experimental design, the loss function, robust design, and the reduction of variation have influenced fields beyond product design and manufacturing, such as [[sales process engineering]].{{cite book |title=Sales Process Engineering: A Personal Workshop |last=Selden |first=Paul H. |publisher=ASQ Quality Press |location = Milwaukee, WI| year=1997 |pages=156?158, 169, 237}} ==Contributions== {{main|Taguchi methods}} Taguchi has made a very influential contribution to industrial statistics. Key elements of his quality philosophy include the following: #[[Taguchi loss function]], used to measure financial loss to society resulting from poor quality; #The philosophy of ''off-line quality control'', designing products and processes so that they are insensitive ("robust") to parameters outside the design engineer's control. #Innovations in the statistical [[design of experiments]], notably the use of an outer array for factors that are uncontrollable in real life, but are systematically varied in the experiment. ==Honours== *1960 - Deming Prize for Individuals *1986 - [[Willard F. Rockwell Medal]] of the [[International Technology Institute]] *1989 - [[Medals of Honour (Japan)#Blue ribbon|Indigo Ribbon]] from the [[Emperor of Japan]] *1990 - Honoured as a Quality Guru by the British Department of Trade and Industry *1995 - Honorary member of the [[Japanese Society of Quality Control]] *1997 - [[Automotive Hall of Fame]] Inductee *1998 - Honorary member of the [[American Society for Quality]] *1998 - Honorary member of the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] *1999 - Honorary president of the [[Robust Quality Engineering Society]] (Japan) ==Book== *{{Cite book|title=Taguchi on Robust Technology Development: Bringing Quality Engineering Upstream|author=Genichi Taguchi|publisher=ASME Press|date=August 1992|isbn=978-0791800287}} *{{Cite book|title=Robust Engineering: Learn How to Boost Quality while Reducing Costs & Time to Market|author1=Genichi Taguchi |author2=Subir Chowdhury |author3=Shin Taguchi |publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional|date=October 1999|isbn=978-0071347822}} *{{Cite book|title=The Mahalanobis-Taguchi System|author1=Genichi Taguchi |author2=Subir Chowdhury |author3=Yuin Wu |publisher=McGraw Hill Professional|date=August 2000|isbn=978-0071362634}} *{{Cite book|title=The Mahalanobis-Taguchi Strategy : A Pattern Technology System|author1=Genichi Taguchi |author2=Rajesh Jugulum |publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2002|isbn=978-0471023333}} *{{Cite book|title=Computer-Based Robust Engineering: Essential For DFSS|author1=Genichi Taguchi |author2=Rajesh Jugulum |author3=Shin Taguchi |publisher=Amer Society for Quality|year=2004|isbn=978-0873896221}} *{{Cite book|title=Taguchi's Quality Engineering Handbook|author1=Genichi Taguchi |author2=Subir Chowdhury |author3=Yuin Wu |publisher=John Wiley|year=2005|isbn=978-0471413349}} ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.york.ac.uk/depts/maths/histstat/people/taguchi.gif Photograph of Dr. Genichi Taguchi] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Taguchi, Genichi}} [[Category:Aoyama Gakuin University faculty]] [[Category:Japanese business theorists]] [[Category:Japanese industrial engineers]] [[Category:Quality]] [[Category:Quality experts]] [[Category:Japanese statisticians]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]]

[[File:Herman Kähler i sit værksted.jpg|thumb|''Herman Kähler in his Workshop'', painting by [[L.A. Ring]] (1890)]] '''Herman August Kähler''', usually known as '''Herman A. Kähler''', (6 March 1846 – 16 November 1917) was a Danish ceramic designer and manufacturer who ran the Kähler ceramic factory (''[[Kählers Keramiske Værksted]]'') in [[Næstved]], Denmark.<ref name="Campbell2006">{{cite book|last=Campbell|first=Gordon|title=Kähler, Herman August: The Grove Encyclopedia of Decorative Arts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i3Od9bcGus0C&pg=PA464|year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-518948-3|page=464}}</ref>
==Early life== Kähler was the son of Joachim Christian Herman Kähler (1808-1884) from the [[Duchy of Holstein]] who established a pottery workshop in Næstved in 1839. Herman attended the Technical School in Copenhagen (1864–65) while studying privately under [[Herman Wilhelm Bissen]]. Thereafter he travelled to Germany, Switzerland and Paris, returning to Næstved at the end of 1867.<ref name=dbl/>
==Career==
[[File:Kahler - Four-handled vase with crackle glaze.jpg|thumb|120px|Four-handled Kähler vase with crackle glaze (1900)]] Together with his younger brother Carl Frederik Kähler, he took over the running of the factory in 1872.<ref name=ceramicstoday>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceramicstoday.com/articles/danish_ceramics7.htm|title=Danish Ceramics VII - The Turn of the Century|author=Tove Jespersen|publisher=Ceramics Today|accessdate=25 October 2014 |language=}}</ref> Carl became responsible for producing faiance while Herman specialized in manufacturing tiled stoves. In 1875, after Carl withdrew, Herman built a new factory on the town's outskirts where he produced both stoves and pottery.<ref name=dbl>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/index.php?title=Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Handel_og_industri/Fabrikant/Herman_A._K%C3%A4hler|title=Herman A. Kähler|publisher=''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon''|accessdate=25 October 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
As a result of his collaboration with the artist [[Vilhelm Klein]], Kähler became interested in obtaining the red lustre glaze known as [[maiolica]] which had been produced in [[Gubbio]], Italy, in the 16th century. In 1888 he succeeded, developing the now famous ruby glaze known as Kähler red.<ref name=ceramicstoday/> The designer [[Karl Hansen Reistrup]] (1863–1929) soon joined the enterprise, assisting in the production of finely formed, artistically decorated items, especially vases.<ref name=dbl/> Thanks to Reistrup's designs, Kähler's ceramics achieved considerable success both at the [[Nordic Exhibition of 1888|Great Nordic Exhibition]] held in Copenhagen in 1888 and at the [[Exposition Universelle (1889)|Exposition Universelle]] held the following year in Paris.<ref name="Campbell2006"/> A number of other artists began to design items for the Kähler factory, including [[Thorvald Bindesbøll]], [[H. A. Brendekilde]], [[L.A. Ring]] and [[Svend Hammershøi]]. Their contributions further enhanced the firm's international success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/index.php?title=Kunst_og_kultur/Kunsth%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk_og_design/Kunsth%C3%A5ndv%C3%A6rk_i_Danmark_efter_1850/Herman_August_K%C3%A4hler|title=Herman A. Kähler|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=25 October 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
Kähler died in Næstved in 1917. His son Herman Hans Christian Kähler (1876-1940) who had taken over management of the factory in 1901 continued to run the enterprise.<ref name=ceramicstoday/>

{{advert|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox non-profit |name = INJAZ Al-Arab |slogan = "Belief in the boundless potential of Arab youth." |location = [https://www.google.jo/maps/place/Injaz+Al+Arab/@31.962726,35.896127,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x9a5486612c1d9d78?sa=X&ei=KqZhVY3nG4rTUavOgdgF&ved=0CG8Q_BIwCg Amman, Jordan] |founded_date = 2004 |area_served = [[MENA]] |homepage = [http://www.injazalarab.org www.injazalarab.org] |image = INJAZALRAB-LOGO-ENG.jpg |image_size = 250px }}
'''INJAZ Al-Arab ''' ([[Arabic]]: إنجاز العرب) is a [[non-profit organization]] for education and training in workforce readiness, [[financial literacy]] and [[entrepreneurship]] across [[the Arab World]]. INJAZ Al-Arab is the Regional Operating Center of JA Worldwide (JAW),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaworldwide.org/ |title=JA Worldwide | date=2015 |website=JA Worldwide |access-date=24 May 2015}}</ref> one of the largest global [[non-governmental organizations]] dedicated to addressing fundamental social and economic challenges facing young people by educating and empowering them to transform their future and own the economic success. INJAZ Al-Arab is also an active participant in the [[United Nations Global Compact|United Nations Global Compact.]] Over 3 million students have participated in a broad base of [[entrepreneurship]] training opportunities aimed at developing basic business skills to start and run their own businesses while obtaining soft skills increasingly demanded by the [[private sector]]. INJAZ Al-Arab has over 45,000 classroom volunteers, who are leaders from the corporate world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.injazalarab.org/ |title=INJAZ Al-Arab | date=2015 |website=INJAZ Al-Arab |access-date=24 May 2015}}</ref> INJAZ Al-Arab has a Regional Board of Directors, which comprises 22 executives that manage some companies and institutions, as well as a team of staff, led by Akef Aqrabawi, President and CEO of Middle East/North Africa for Junior Achievement Worldwide, INJAZ Al-Arab. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.injazalarab.org/about/#Staff |title=INJAZ Al-Arab's Staff |website=INJAZ Al-Arab |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.injazalarab.org/about/#BoardofDirectors |title=INJAZ Al-Arab's Board of Directors |website=INJAZ Al-Arab |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://skollworldforum.org/contributor/akef-aqrabawi/ |title=AKEF AQRABAWI, CEO, INJAZ AL-ARAB |website=Skoll World Forum Online |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref>
Other INJAZ branches exist in Qatar,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.injaz-qatar.org/en/content/ashraf-abu-issa|title=Ashraf Abu Issa {{!}} INJAZ Qatar|website=www.injaz-qatar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref> Egypt,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.injaz-egypt.org|title=Injaz Egypt|website=www.injaz-egypt.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref> Bahrain.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://injazbh.org/|title=INJAZ Bahrain|website=injazbh.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Injaz-updated map.pdf|left|thumb|INJAZ Al-Arab's Region Map]] INJAZ Al-Arab began its work in the Middle East & North Africa ([[MENA]]) region in 1999 and joining [[Junior Achievement]], established its regional office in 2004. Since joining JA, and under INJAZ Al-Arab's founder and former CEO Soraya Salti's leadership, INJAZ grew in program availability, student participation, and reach. Today, it operates in 14 countries as a federation of national operations. INJAZ Al-Arab's network includes Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Kuwait, Lebanon, Morocco, Oman, Pakistan, Palestine, Qatar<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.injaz-qatar.org/|title=INJAZ Qatar|website=www.injaz-qatar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates, and Yemen.
== Activities == INJAZ Al-Arab's programs focus on three core areas of business education which are:
*'''Work Readiness''': The widespread mismatch between the skills attained in school and those demanded by the private sector are feeding current youth unemployment rates. INJAZ Al-Arab programs build teamwork, critical thinking, problem solving, communication, and leadership skills employers look for. *'''Financial Literacy''': Teaching young people about responsible money management is key to building their own financial security and an economically prosperous future for themselves. *'''Entrepreneurship''': Entrepreneurship education prepares youth to be responsible, enterprising individuals. Immersing them in real life learning experiences allows them to take measured risks, manage the results, and learn from the outcomes. This growing number of youth led enterprises creates new jobs and fuels economic development.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jaworldwide.org/ja-works/Pages/JAs-Core-Content.aspx|title=JA's Core Content|website=JA Worldwide|access-date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
== Sponsors == The Abraaj Group, Bin Zayed Group, [[Gulf Bank of Kuwait|Gulf Bank]], [[Middle East Broadcasting Center|MBC Group]], [[Arab League Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization|ALECSO]], [[Boeing]], [[HSBC]], [[National Bank of Kuwait|NBK]], [[Alghanim Industries]], [[Citigroup|Citi Foundation]], [[Intel]], [[Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship]], Amwal, [[J.P. Morgan & Co.]], [[Skoll Foundation]], [[Aramex]], [[Deloitte]], [[The Henry R. Kravis Prize in Nonprofit Leadership|Kravis Prize]], [[The Bank of New York Mellon]], [[ExxonMobil]], [[FedEx]], [[MasterCard]], [[Google]], [[Marriott International]], [[Investcorp]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.injazalarab.org/regional-partners/#RegionalPartners|title=Regional Partners |access-date=26 May 2015}}</ref>
== Knowledge Partners == [[Arab League Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization|ALECSO]], Bayt, [[Deloitte]], [[DLA Piper]], [[Hill+Knowlton Strategies]], [[McKinsey & Company]], [[Oliver Wyman]], Meysan, [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]], Visual Laundry, [[World Economic Forum]], [[World Bank]], [[YouGov]], [[Engie]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.injazalarab.org/regional-partners/#RegionalPartners|title=Regional Partners |access-date=26 May 2015}}</ref>
== Awards ==
INJAZ Al-Arab and Soraya Salti, former CEO, was awarded [[The Henry R. Kravis Prize in Nonprofit Leadership]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kravisprize.cmc.edu/prize-recipients/soraya-salti/ |title=Soraya Salti & INJAZ Al-Arab | date=2012 |website=The Kravis Prize in Non-Profit Leadership |access-date=24 May 2015}}</ref>
INJAZ Al-Arab, along with six other organizations throughout the world, was awarded the [[Skoll Foundation]] for Social Entrepreneurship in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skollfoundation.org/skoll-foundation-adds-seven-organizations-to-its-portfolio-of-leading-social-entrepreneurs/ |title=Skoll Foundation Adds Seven Organizations to its Portfolio of Leading Social Entrepreneurs | date=2009 |website=Skoll Foundation |access-date=26 May 2015}}</ref>
A 2012 study supported by Citi Foundation by professors from Harvard and [[Dubai School of Government]] (now named Mohammed Bin Rashid School of Government''')''' found that INJAZ Al-Arab alumni have a significantly shorter waiting period than other youth while searching for jobs after graduation. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jaworldwide.org/inside-ja/Reports/INJAZ_Al_Arab_Final_Evaluation_Report.pdf|title=Unlocking Arab Youth Entrepreneurship Potential | date=2012 |access-date=24 May 2015}}</ref>
Named one of the top 100 NGOs in the world by [[The Global Journal]] for five consecutive years, INJAZ Al-Arab has influenced the lives of over 2.7 million students since its inception in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theglobaljournal.net/article/view/497/ |title=#96 INJAZ Al-Arab | date=2012 |website=The Global Journal |access-date=24 May 2015}}</ref>
== INJAZ Al-Arab in the News == [[Queen Rania of Jordan]] is a supporter of INJAZ Al-Arab. In 2015, she chaired a discussion with entrepreneurs in celebration of INJAZ Al-Arab's 10th anniversary, showcasing alumni's success stories.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/11/biz-07women_Queen-Rania_VZPS.html |title=Queen Rania | date=August 2007 |website=Forbes |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.queenrania.jo/media/press/queen-rania-chairs-discussion-entrepreneurs-injaz-al-arab-celebrating-its-10th-anniversa |title=Queen Rania chairs a discussion with entrepreneurs from INJAZ Al-Arab celebrating its 10th anniversary | date=January 2015 |website=Queen Rania Al Abdullah |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://kravisprize.cmc.edu/jordans-queen-leads-event-in-praise-of-injaz-al-arabs-success/ |title=Jordan’s queen leads event in praise of Injaz Al-Arab’s success | date=January 2015 |website=The Kravis Prize in Non-Profit Leadership |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref>
INJAZ Al-Arab is frequent in the [[Skoll Foundation]] website, whose mission is to drive large-scale change by investing in, connecting, and celebrating social entrepreneurs and the innovators who help them solve the world’s most pressing problems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skollfoundation.org/tag/injaz/ |title=INJAZ AL-ARAB |website=Skoll Foundation |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref>
INJAZ Al-Arab has been mentioned several times in The Skoll World Forum Online, a year-round platform that focuses on a variety of areas, including education and economic opportunity. The Skoll World Forum Online is affiliated with the [[Skoll Foundation]]. Akef Aqrabawi, President and CEO of Middle East/North Africa for Junior Achievement Worldwide. INJAZ Al-Arab has also been featured on the website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://skollworldforum.org/contributor/akef-aqrabawi/ |title=AKEF AQRABAWI, CEO, INJAZ AL-ARAB |website=Skoll World Forum Online |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://skollworldforum.org/organization/injaz-al-arab/ |title=INJAZ AL-ARAB |website=Skoll World Forum Online |access-date=28 May 2015}}</ref>
Soraya Salti, who has also been awarded the Skoll Foundation Award in 2009, has been listed as a social entrepreneur with the [[Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship]]. [[Harvard School of Business]] | part = [[Liberal Party of Canada]] | occupation = lawyer, business person }} '''James Allan Coutts''' {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|size=100%|CM}} (May 16, 1938 – December 31, 2013) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[lawyer]], [[businessman]], and former advisor to two [[Prime Minister of Canada|prime minister]]s. ==Biography== Born in [[High River]], [[Alberta]], he was raised in [[Nanton, Alberta]]. He received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1960 and a law degree in 1961 from the [[University of Alberta]] and an [[MBA]] from the [[Harvard Business School]] in 1968. He was called to Bar of Alberta in 1962. From 1961 to 1963, he practiced law in [[Calgary, Alberta]]. From 1963 to 1966, he was a Secretary to [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Lester B. Pearson]]. After receiving his MBA, he was a Consultant with [[McKinsey & Company]] from 1968 to 1970. From 1970 to 1975, he was a Partner with The Canada Consulting Group. From 1975 to 1981, he was the [[Principal Secretary (Canada)|Principal Secretary]] to Prime Minister [[Pierre Elliott Trudeau]]. In 1981, Trudeau appointed Liberal MP [[Peter Stollery]] to the [[Senate of Canada|Senate]] so Coutts could run for the [[House of Commons of Canada]] in what was thought of as the safe Ontario riding of [[Spadina (electoral district)|Spadina]]. The plan backfired when Coutts narrowly lost to [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democrat]] [[Dan Heap]] despite personal interventions from Trudeau. Coutts ran again, but lost by a heavier margin in the [[Canadian federal election, 1984|1984 election]]. He subsequently left politics and entered business with an international career in industrial explosives. He was a principal of Lowther Consultants Limited and the chairman and chief executive officer of CIC Canadian Investment Capital Limited.{{cite news|title=Jim Coutts, key adviser to former PMs Pearson and Trudeau, dies of cancer|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/key-adviser-to-former-pms-pearson-trudeau-dies-of-cancer/article16160079/|accessdate=January 1, 2014|newspaper=Globe and Mail|date=January 1, 2014|location=Toronto}} He was also a philanthropist and a major donor to the [[University of Lethbridge]]. He was a member of the Board and Foundation of [[The Hospital for Sick Children]] and was a co-founder of the [[W.O. Mitchell Literary Prize]]. In 2001, he was made a Member of the [[Order of Canada]]. Coutts died of cancer on December 31, 2013.{{cite news|author=Gallant, Jacques|date=January 1, 2014| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2014/01/01/jim_coutts_pearson_and_trudeau_advisor_dead_at_75.html |title=Jim Coutts, Pearson and Trudeau advisor, dead at 75| newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} ==Electoral history== {{Canadian federal by-election, 17 August 1981/Spadina}} {{Canadian federal election, 1984/Spadina}} == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == * {{cite web|url=http://www.utpress.utoronto.ca/cgi-bin/cw2w3.cgi?p=corn&t=96297&d=1388 |title=Canadian Who's Who 1997 entry |work=[[University of Toronto Press]] }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * {{cite web|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/ALUMNI/newtrail/01-1/trudeau3.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20060929092817/http://www.ualberta.ca/ALUMNI/newtrail/01-1/trudeau3.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-09-29 |title=Their Trudeau Years |work=University of Alberta }} == External links == * [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0001971 James Allan Coutts] at [[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Coutts, Jim}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Lawyers in Alberta]] [[Category:Candidates in the 1984 Canadian federal election]] [[Category:McKinsey & Company people]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:Members of the United Church of Canada]] [[Category:People from the Municipal District of Foothills No. 31]] [[Category:People from the Municipal District of Willow Creek No. 26]] [[Category:University of Alberta alumni]] [[Category:People from High River]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Ontario]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Canada candidates for the Canadian House of Commons]]

'''Juan Mauricio Wurmser''' is a founding partner, President and [[CEO]] of [[Wurmser Ogilvy & Mather]], the O&M advertising firm in [[Guatemala]]. He is also founding partner and [[Chairman of Hill + Knowlton Strategies]] [[Guatemala]], the local subsidiary of this international public relations firm. He is a member of the Ogilvy Latina Executive Committee where he represents the Central American and Caribbean operations. Mr. Wurmser is involved in other business ventures in the marketing services and communications areas that include 141 Soho Square, MEC, Mindshare and Mediacom, all part of the WPP Group. He has more than 30 years of experience in the marketing of consumer goods throughout Latin America and a history of active participation in business chambers and organizations, as well as a spell of public service with the government of [[Guatemala]] .
==Prior History== Prior to joining WO&M and [[Hill and Knowlton]] [[Guatemala]] in mid-1998, Mr. Wurmser served as [[Minister of Economy]] of [[Guatemala]]. He was responsible for trade and industry promotion - with special emphasis on attracting foreign investment - and coordinated the regional and [[world|global]] economic integration efforts of the [[Arzú]] administration. He was a key member of the [[Guatemala]]n Economic Cabinet and sat on the Monetary Board where monetary, credit and exchange policies were defined. He was also Chairman of the Board of Governors of the [[Central American]] [[Bank of Economic]] Integration between 1997 and 1998.
Before taking up public service, Mr. Wurmser was responsible for developing and implementing the franchise program of [[Pollo Campero]], one of the most successful fast food restaurant chains in [[Central America]], which led to its [[international]] expansion.
His years as a corporate [[marketing]] executive include early assignments with the [[Guatemala]] subsidiaries of Warner Lambert, Avon, and [[Colgate-Palmolive]], before joining British American Tobacco in 1978, a company that he served for 15 years in [[Guatemala]], [[Panama]], [[Spain]], [[Mexico]], and [[Argentina]] before returning to [[Guatemala]] as President and General Manager of its local subsidiary.
Juan Mauricio has been committed to fostering Guatemala' s viability through his participation in business chambers and organisations through the years.
More recently, he was chosen by The Guatemalan Management Association as CEO of the Year 2015, one of the most coveted awards of the regional business community, followed by the early 2016 recognition as Guatemala's Entrepreneur of the Year by the Central American edition of The Economist magazine.
In mid 2016, affiliation agreements were signed by the Wurmser Communications Group with MEC and Mindshare, two of the global premier Media Investment Management companies, thus expanding further the WPP Group footprint in Guatemala and the Central American region.
==Other information== A native of Guatemala [[City]], Mr. Wurmser holds a B.S. in business administration from [[The College of New Jersey]] (formerly Trenton State College) and also attended the graduate school of business of [[Universidad Francisco Marroquín]] in [[Guatemala]].
Mr. Wurmser has been a member of the Board of Directors of the Chamber of Industry of [[Guatemala]], was Chairman of the Business Chamber of [[Guatemala]] in 1993 and also sat on the Board of Directors of the [[American Chamber of Commerce]] of [[Guatemala]] ([[AMCHAM]]) in 2009. He has been a board member of the [[Guatemala]]n [[Advertising Association]] ([[UGAP]]) over the years, having chaired it in 2001 and in 2013-2014. At present, he is also a member of the [[Board of Trustees]] of the [[Guatemala]] Development Foundation ([[FUNDESA]]) .

{{nihongo|'''Kunio Egashira'''|江頭 邦雄|Egashira Kunio|extra=October 1, 1937<ref name="iza">{{cite news |url=http://www.iza.ne.jp/izaword/word/%25E6%25B1%259F%25E9%25A0%25AD%25E9%2582%25A6%25E9%259B%2584/ |script-title=ja:江頭邦雄：イザ！ |publisher=[[Iza (publisher)|Iza]] |language=Japanese |date=2006-07-26 |accessdate=2008-04-21}}</ref> – April 7, 2008}} was the [[Japan]]ese [[chairman]] of [[Ajinomoto]], a [[Japanese food]] company which specializes in [[seasoning]] and [[flavoring]]s.
Egashira was born in [[Nagasaki Prefecture]] and graduated from [[Hitotsubashi University]] with a degree in economics.<ref name="iza" />
Egashira became president of Ajinomoto in June 1997.<ref name=reuters> {{cite news |first=Taiga |last=Uranaka|title=Ajinomoto chairman Kunio Egashira, 70, dies |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/marketsNews/idUST17677720080409 |work= [[Reuters]] |publisher= |date=2008-04-09 |accessdate=2008-04-19}}</ref> He pushed through a very aggressive array of business reforms as president. He realigned Ajinomoto to focus on growth areas within the [[food industry]], with an emphasis on [[amino acid]] technology.<ref name=reuters/>
Egashira became president following a scandal at the company. His predecessor stepped down as president to take over the managerial responsibility at Ajinomoto.<ref name=reuters/> Two company officials were [[indicted]] for making illegal payments to [[corporate]] [[racketeer]]s.<ref name=reuters/>
Egashira became chairman of the company in June 2005.<ref name=reuters/>
Kunio Egashira died on April 7, 2008, of [[pancreatic cancer]] at the age of 70.<ref name=reuters/>

'''New Entrepreneurs Foundation''' (NEF), founded in 2010, is a London-based [[nonprofit organization]] that runs development programmes for aspiring [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newentrepreneursfoundation.com|title=New Entrepreneurs Foundation|website=New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
==History== Founded in 2010 by Oliver Pawle, Dee Stirling, [[Nigel Rudd|Sir Nigel Rudd]] and [[Mervyn Davies, Baron Davies of Abersoch|The Lord Davies of Abersoch CBE]], the NEF was designed to support the next generation of UK entrepreneurs building new businesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/|title=About Us - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
In 2013, the organisation launched a guide for social entrepreneurs.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/social-enterprise-network/2013/dec/19/new-guide-tips-advice-social-entrepreneur</ref>
In 2017, it was announced a new organisation would be set up by NEF and The Centre for Entrepreneurs to work on long-term challenges to entrepreneurship in the United Kingdom. One million pounds was donated to the project by [[Mikhail Fridman]].<ref>https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/oligarch-s-helping-hand-for-the-next-generation-bvpq20d9m</ref>
==Organisation== NEF solely focuses on the entrepreneurial potential of its intake rather than existing venture ideas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/what-we-look-for/|title=What we look for - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> It does not require the contribution of equity from its participants’ ventures. It is entirely funded through corporate and individual sponsorship. See Sponsors and Funding for more information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/our-sponsors/|title=Our sponsors - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Based in London the organisation's direction is decided by a [[Board of trustees|Board of Trustees]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/our-leadership/|title=Our leadership - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> and CEO Neeta Patel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/executive-team/|title=Executive team - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
== Courses == The NEF runs a yearly programme with up to fifty candidates. The candidates project can be anywhere from the ideas stage to running a venture full-time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studenttimes.org/article/news/graduate-news/forty-aspiring-entrepreneurs-be-selected-new-entrepreneur-training#.V56M66Ky47E|title=Forty Aspiring Entrepreneurs To Be Selected For New Entrepreneur Training Programme - Student Times|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/meet-class-of-2015/meet-our-alumni/|title=Meet our alumni - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/faq/|title=FAQs - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
The course has several components including:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/|title=What is the NEF Programme? - The New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
* Paid Work Placement - placements with start-ups such as [[Secret Escapes]], [[Uber (company)|Uber]] and E-Leather.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://startups.co.uk/new-entrepreneurs-foundation-hunt-young-entrepreneurs-tomorrow/|title=New Entrepreneurs Foundation on hunt for 'young entrepreneurs of tomorrow' - Startups.co.uk: Starting a business advice and business ideas|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref>
* Learning and Development Workshops - training workshops provided in partnership with business schools, including [[University College London|UCL]], [[London Business School]] and other specialist training providers. Workshops cover topics such as [[Negotiation]], [[Web development|Web Development]] and [[Sales pitch|Pitching]].
* Speaker Series - Past speakers include [[Dido Harding]] (CEO, [[TalkTalk Group|Talk Talk]]), Gerry Murphy,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blackstone.com/the-firm/our-people/person?person=1000602|title=Gerry Murphy|website=www.blackstone.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> (Chairman, [[The Blackstone Group|Blackstone]]), [[Hermann Hauser|Dr. Hermann Hauser CBE]] (co-founder, [[Amadeus Capital Partners]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amadeuscapital.com/|title=Home page - Amadeus Capital|website=Amadeus Capital|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>), [[Lara Morgan]] (co-founder, [[Startup Britain|StartUp Britain]]), Brett Akker (founder, Streetcar, now [[Zipcar]]) and Marcia Kilgore (founder, Bliss, FitFlop & the Soap & Glory range<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://uk.linkedin.com/in/marcia-kilgore-15a3646|title=Marcia Kilgore {{!}} LinkedIn|website=uk.linkedin.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>)
* [[Coaching]] - an executive coach to help with personal development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/coaches/|title=Coaches - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
* [[Mentorship]] - a business mentor from a specific industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/mentors/|title=Business Mentors for Entrepreneurs|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Each June the current cohort and alumni pitch their business ventures to a panel of investors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://us2.campaign-archive2.com/?u=a848bbe94ddea0cc8e6d81ea0&id=81f1eabca0&e=%255BUNIQID%255D|title=NEF Celebrates 5 Years of Developing Entrepreneurs|website=us2.campaign-archive2.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
==Business== As of July 2016, NEF has developed 155 entrepreneurial ventures, of which 62 remain active, with more than £10m in investment raised and 650 jobs created.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/what-we-have-achieved/|title=What we have achieved - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Among these businesses<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/meet-class-of-2015/nef-ventures/|title=NEF Ventures - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> are Inkpact,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inkpact.com|title=Personalised Communication {{!}} Inkpact.com {{!}} Improved Marketing|website=www.inkpact.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Pollen8,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pollen8.io/|title=pollen8 - Work done better together|website=pollen8.io|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Plus44 Holdings (whose primary product is Sliide App),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sliideairtime.ng/|title=Sliide Airtime|website=sliideairtime.ng|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Stand4Socks,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stand4socks.com/|title=Stand4 Socks - Socks for Social Causes - StandOut Stand4!|website=Stand4Socks|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Krzana,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.krzana.com/|title=Krzana - The Real-Time Search Engine|website=www.krzana.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Wiser,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wearewiser.com/|title=Wiser|website=wearewiser.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Sideways6,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sideways6.com|title=Sideways 6 – Crowdsourcing Employee Ideas with Office 365 and Yammer|website=www.sideways6.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Turn Partners<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.turnpartners.com|title=Turn Partners|website=www.turnpartners.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> and CharlieHR.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charliehr.com/|title=Charlie – The free HR platform for startups|website=www.charliehr.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>

[[Bettina Moissi]] | nationality = Germany, United States | religion = | spouse = | children = | salary = | signature = }} '''Nicolas Berggruen''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ɜr|g|r|uː|n|,_|b|ɜr|ˈ|g|r|uː|ən}};[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAUNOL_d8YM&t=8s "Nicolas Berggruen on 'Giving Pledge' and think tanks"]; [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DHyReesbTFI&t=5s "Investing in Ideas: CNN Interview with Nicolas Berggruen"]. born 10 August 1961) is a philanthropist and investor. A dual American and German citizen,Jeremy Kahn (October 25, 2011), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-25/billionaire-living-out-of-tote-bag-amasses-fortune-to-give-away.html Billionaire Living Out of Tote Bag Amasses Fortune to Give Away] ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' he is the founder and president of Berggruen Holdings, a private investment company and the [[Berggruen Institute]], a think tank that works on addressing governance issues as well as the cultures and philosophies behind political systems. Through the Berggruen Institute he is also a co-founder, with the Washington Post, of The WorldPost, a media publication dedicated to global issues.{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/25/with-some-investing-help-huffington-unveils-a-new-international-venture/|title=With Some Investing Help, Huffington Unveils a New International Venture|first=Michael J. de la|last=Merced|publisher=}} ==Education and business career== Berggruen was born in Paris, the son of art collector [[Heinz Berggruen]],[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-09-27/deep-thoughts-with-the-homeless-billionaire Businessweek: "Deep Thoughts With the Homeless Billionaire" By Devin Leonard] September 27, 2012 and actress [[Bettina Moissi]]. His father was of [[German-Jewish]] descent and his mother a [[Catholic]][http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-52909367.html Der Spiegel: "Seinen Geist am Leben erhalten" by Ulrike Von Knöfel and Martin Doerry (in German)] ''"Meine Mutter ist katholisch, mein Vater jüdisch" / My mother is Catholic, my father is Jewish'' of [[German people|German]] and [[Italian/Albanian people|Italian/Albanian]] descent. Berggruen attended the École Alsacienne in Paris and [[Le Rosey]] in Switzerland, before completing a [[baccalauréat]] in Paris as a candidat libre in 1978.Stacy Meichtry (September 29, 2011), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111904836104576556982258399652#ixzz1qhloiCVU Man Without a Country] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.Jori Finkel (March 18, 2012), [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-ca-nicolas-berggruen-20120318,0,1625885.story?page=1 Nicolas Berggruen explains why he intends to give art to LACMA] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. He worked as a trainee at [[London Merchant Securities]] in London, known today as LMS Capital Plc. He subsequently obtained a [[Bachelor of Science]] in Finance and International Business from [[New York University]] in 1981. He later worked for the investment company [[Robert Bass|Bass Brothers Enterprises]], in its real estate group.[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/10/billionaires-2010_Nicolas-Berggruen_EX9R.html Nicolas Berggruen] ''[[Forbes]]''. Between 1983 and 1987, Berggruen was a Principal at Jacobson and Co.{{cn|date=June 2017}} In New York, based on a trust fund worth about $250,000, Berggruen began buying real estate before moving on to stocks, bonds and a portfolio of private equity and venture funds as well as hedge funds. He founded Berggruen Holdings, Inc. in 1984 to act as investment adviser to a Berggruen family trust. In 1988, he and [[Julio Mario Santo Domingo, Jr.]] co-founded Alpha Investment Management, a [[hedge fund]] that was reportedly sold to [[Safra Bank]] in 2004.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4eca9d52-1f55-11e0-8c1c-00144feab49a.html |title=Lunch with the FT: Nicolas Berggruen |work=[[Financial Times]] |first=Gillian |last=Tett | authorlink =Gillian Tett|date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2011}} The press has referred to Berggruen as "the homeless billionaire", as at one point he lived in hotels and did not own a home.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/09/25/MNK21L6IF8.DTL |date=25 September 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2011 |last=Garofoli |first=Joe |title=Can billionaire Nicolas Berggruen fix California? |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |via=SFGate.com}}{{cite web|last1=Curwen|first1=Tom|title=On his Santa Monica mountaintop, a billionaire envisions lofty thoughts on politics and culture|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-nicolas-berggruen-think-tank-20160429-snap-story.html|website=L.A. Times|accessdate=1 May 2016}} ==Berggruen Institute== ===Berggruen Governance Center=== In 2010, Berggruen founded the [[Berggruen Institute]], a self-styled "think and action tank." Through the institute, he has launched several government reform projects including the 21st Century Council which is focused on global governance challenges, the [[Council for the Future of Europe]], to support work on [[European integration]] and the ''Think Long Committee for California'', a bipartisan effort focused on reforming California's system of governance.{{cite web |url=http://www.sacbee.com/2011/11/20/4065880/thinking-long-about-states-future.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419020036/http://www.sacbee.com/2011/11/20/4065880/thinking-long-about-states-future.html |archivedate=2012-04-19 |df= }} In 2015, Berggruen announced the launch of the Berggruen Philosophy and Culture Center.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/16/arts/nicolas-berggruen-wants-to-bridge-the-east-west-gap.html|title=Nicolas Berggruen Wants to Bridge the East-West Gap|date=16 September 2015|work=The New York Times|accessdate=1 May 2016}} Berggruen is a co-author (with [[Nathan Gardels]]) of a book on political governance: ''[[Intelligent Governance for the 21st Century]]: A Middle Way Between West and East'', written with Nathan Gardels (Polity, 2012). The ''[[Financial Times]]'' named it as one of their "Best Books of 2012".[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/88bdb3c0-37cf-11e2-a97e-00144feabdc0.html Financial Times: "Best books of 2012"] December 3, 2012 ===Berggruen Philosophy and Culture Center=== In September 2015, Berggruen announced the launch of the Berggruen Institute's Philosophy and Culture Center. The Center includes a fellowship program between Chinese and American universities, an ideas contest, and an annual $1 million philosophy prize to be awarded by an international jury. ==Institutional affiliations== Berggruen is a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]],{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/about/membership/roster.html?letter=B|title=Membership Roster|work=Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=1 May 2016}} Director on the Board of the [[Pacific Council on International Policy]], a member of Foro Iberoamericano, a member of the [[Helena Group]], and a member of the Commission on Global Ethics and Citizenship. In 2013 he was appointed by Harvard's Center for European Studies as its first non-resident Senior Fellow,{{cite web |url=https://ces.fas.harvard.edu/files/front/BerggruenPressRelease.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023061933/https://ces.fas.harvard.edu/files/front/BerggruenPressRelease.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-23 |df= }} and was named a member of the Brookings International Advisory Council and the NYU President's Global Council.{{cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/support-brookings/getting-involved/international-advisory-council|title=International Advisory Council|work=The Brookings Institution|accessdate=1 May 2016}} In 2014 he was named a member of the Leadership Council at [[John F. Kennedy School of Government|Harvard Kennedy School]]'s [[Center for Public Leadership]], a member of Harvard University's Global Advisory Council, as well as a trustee of the [[Asia Society]].{{cite web|url=http://asiasociety.org/about/trustees|title=Co-Chairs and Trustees|work=Asia Society|accessdate=1 May 2016}} He is also a member of the [[World Economic Forum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/nicolas-berggruen|title=Nicolas Berggruen - World Economic Forum|work=World Economic Forum|accessdate=1 May 2016}} ==Arts== Berggruen is the head of the Board of the [[Berggruen Museum]] in Berlin and a member of the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art|Los Angeles County Museum]] (LACMA), the International Councils of the [[Tate Gallery]] in London, and the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York. He is also a member of the Beyeler Foundation, the International Council of the [[Serpentine Gallery]],{{cite web|url=http://www.serpentinegallery.org/support.html|title=Support|work=Serpentine Galleries|accessdate=1 May 2016}} and [[Sotheby's]] International Advisory Board.{{cite web|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/inside/board-of-directors.html|title=Sotheby's - Board of Directors|work=sothebys.com|accessdate=1 May 2016}} In cooperation with LACMA, he has been making acquisitions intended for the museum. ==Philanthropy== Berggruen has committed to give the majority of his wealth through the Nicolas Berggruen Charitable Trust{{cite web|url=http://nicolasberggruentrust.com/|title=Home Page|work=nicolasberggruentrust.com|accessdate=1 May 2016}} and has joined [[The Giving Pledge]].http://givingpledge.org/pdf/letters/Berggruen_Letter.pdf Berggruen has endowed the Berggruen Institute with $500 Million to further the activities and broaden its global reach.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-04/-homeless-billionaire-gets-l-a-welcome-after-500-million-gift|title=`Homeless Billionaire' Charms L.A. With $500 Million Gift|last=chrispalmeri|first=Christopher Palmeri|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-06-16}} Through Berggruen Holdings, Berggruen was a primary investor and developer in Newark, New Jersey's [[Teachers Village (Newark)|Teachers Village]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.teachersvillage.com/team.html|title=Teachers Village {{!}} Team|website=www.teachersvillage.com|access-date=2016-06-16}} He was also honored by his alma mater, [[New York University Stern School of Business|NYU Stern]], at the 2016 Haskins Giving Society Award Dinner for his commitment to business and public service.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stern.nyu.edu/portal-partners/alumni/events/haskins-giving-society-award-dinner|title=NYU Stern {{!}} Haskins Giving Society Award Dinner|website=www.stern.nyu.edu|access-date=2016-06-16}} In 2018, he received the [[Ellis Island Medal of Honor]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.neco.org/medal-of-honor/2018-medalists|title=2018 Ellis Island Medal of Honor Recipients|website=www.neco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-13}} ==Personal life== Berggruen has two children, who were born from one egg-donor and two surrogates.[http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-nicolas-berggruen-think-tank-20160429-snap-story.html Los Angeles Times: "On his Santa Monica mountaintop, a billionaire envisions lofty thoughts on politics and culture" by Thomas Curwen] April 30, 2016 His brother is the art historian [[Olivier Berggruen]]. ==References== (head office).jpg|thumb|Nikkan Kogyo head office in Tokyo]] '''''Nikkan Kogyo Shimbun''''' (日刊工業新聞, The Daily Industrial News), one of the leading daily newspapers in Japan, specializes in business and industrial affairs, and is published by The Nikkan Kogyo Shimbun, Ltd. (Head Office: [[Tokyo]], Japan). Circulation is around 420,000. The newspaper was inaugurated in 1915. It covers economic and industrial affairs in general, and affairs of specific industries such as automobile, electronics, telecommunication, information technologies, science, etc.
Apart from publishing newspapers, the company publishes numerous books and free papers (namely Metro-Guide), and organizes trade fairs (Automotive Parts Product Solution Fair / [[International Robot Exhibition]] / Pan-Exhibition for Wash and Clean etc.) and seminars. Among them, collaboration with [[United Nations Industrial Development Organization]] (UNIDO) is a notable achievement. The two agencies jointly organized a seminar in June 2006, 2007 and 2008, namely "Global Auto Parts Business Seminar", for the purpose of further enhancing Japanese investment (especially auto-parts sector) at newly industrial states.
The newspaper concluded an alliance with [[Asahi Shimbun]] and [[Jiji Press]] in February 2008. Three companies start a new service on information search by internet from April 2008. Japanese name is "KIJISAKU". More than eight million articles and information of three media agencies are put in this service.

Lightweight champion (1956, 1957, 1959, 1962) | commonwealth = | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{NZL}}}} {{MedalSport|Men's [[boxing]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[British Empire Games]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1958 Cardiff]]|[[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games#Boxing|Lightweight]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 Perth]]|[[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games#Boxing|Lightweight]]}} }} '''Thomas Patrick Donovan''' (23 December 1936 – 11 March 2018) was a New Zealand [[amateur boxer]] and [[rugby union]] player. He represented his country in boxing at the [[Boxing at the 1956 Summer Olympics|1956]] and [[Boxing at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Olympic Games]], and won bronze medals at the [[Boxing at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1958]] and [[Boxing at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]]. He also played representative rugby for {{Rut Hawke's Bay}}. ==Early life and family== Born in [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] on 23 December 1936, Donovan was the son of Tommy Donovan, who won the 1927 New Zealand amateur featherweight boxing title, and then had 46 professional bouts between 1929 and 1935.{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12012003 |title=Olympics boxer Paddy Donovan dies in Napier |date=13 March 2018 |work=Hawke's Bay Today |first=Doug |last=Laing |accessdate=27 March 2018}} Paddy Donovan grew up on his family's farm at Meeanee, and was educated at [[St John's College, Hastings]], where he was head boy. ==Boxing== Donovan won his first national amateur boxing title, in the featherweight division, in 1954, while he was still at school. He went on to win the national lightweight title four times—in 1956, 1957, 1959, and 1962—and he was awarded the Jameson Belt for the most scientific boxer in 1956, 1959, and 1962. Donovan won the bronze medal in the men's 57–60 kg (lightweight) division at the [[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]]. Four years later at the [[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] he again won the bronze medal in the same division.{{cite web |url=http://www.olympic.org.nz/athletes/paddy-donovan/ |title=Paddy Donovan |year=2018 |publisher=New Zealand Olympic Committee | accessdate=27 March 2018}} He competed at two [[Summer Olympic Games|Olympics]], not making it past the first round of the lightweight division in [[Boxing at the 1956 Summer Olympics|1956]] and [[Boxing at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964]],{{Cite sports-reference | Paddy Donovan | https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/do/paddy-donovan-1.html | 27 March 2018}} and was controversially omitted from the New Zealand team for the [[New Zealand at the 1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Olympics]]. ==1956 and 1964 Olympic results== Below is the record of Paddy Donovan, a lightweight boxer from New Zealand, who competed at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics: * Round of 32: lost to Toshihito Ishimaru (Japan) on points Below is the record of Paddy Donovan, a lightweight boxer from New Zealand, who competed at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics: * Round of 32: lost to Hector Pace (Argentina) referee stopped contest ==Rugby union== A [[Rugby union positions#Scrum-half|halfback]] and [[Rugby union positions#Fly-half|first five-eighth]], Donovan played for the {{Rut Hawke's Bay}} rugby union team between 1955 and 1959. ==Later life and death== From 1962, Donovan worked as an [[accountant]] in [[Hastings, New Zealand|Hastings]], retiring in 2012 after 50 years. In 2001, he established Ballydooley Cider Ltd on the family orchard. Donovan died in Napier on 11 March 2018. ==References== {{reflist}} {{1956 New Zealand Olympic team}} {{1958 New Zealand British Empire and Commonwealth Games team}} {{1964 New Zealand Olympic team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Donovan, Paddy}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Napier, New Zealand]] [[Category:People educated at St John's College, Hastings]] [[Category:Olympic boxers of New Zealand]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games bronze medallists for New Zealand]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Boxers at the 1964 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:New Zealand male boxers]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in boxing]] [[Category:Hawke's Bay Magpies players]] [[Category:Rugby union scrum-halves]] [[Category:Rugby union fly-halves]] [[Category:New Zealand accountants]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Rugby union players from Napier, New Zealand]]

{{about||the theater|Paper Mill Playhouse|academic papers|Academic paper mill (disambiguation){{!}}Academic paper mill}} [[Image:InternationalPaper6413.jpg|thumb|International Paper Company's Kraft pulp and paper mill in [[Georgetown, South Carolina]]. When built, this was the world's largest mill.]] [[Image:St marys no 5 pm 1 of 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Basement]] of paper mill in [[Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario]]. Pulp and paper manufacture involves a great deal of [[humidity]], which presents a [[preventive maintenance]] and [[corrosion]] challenge.]] A '''paper mill''' is a [[factory]] devoted to making [[paper]] from vegetable fibres such as [[wood pulp]], old rags and other ingredients. Prior to the invention and adoption of the [[Fourdrinier machine]] and other types of [[paper machine]] that use an endless belt, all paper in a paper mill was made by hand, one sheet at a time, by specialized laborers.
== History == {{See also|History of paper}} [[Image:Forest Fibre Company Berlin, New Hampshire.JPG|thumb|left|A mid-19th century paper mill, the Forest Fibre Company, in [[Berlin, New Hampshire]]]]
Historical investigations into the origin of the paper mill are complicated by differing definitions and loose terminology from modern authors: Many modern scholars use the term to refer indiscriminately to all kinds of [[Mill (grinding)|mills]], whether powered by humans, [[horse mill|by animals]] or [[watermill|by water]]. Their propensity to refer to any ancient paper manufacturing centre as a "mill", without further specifying its exact power drive, has increased the difficulty of identifying the particularly efficient and historically important water-powered type.<ref name="Burns 1996, 414−417">{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414−417}}</ref>
=== Human and animal-powered mills === The use of human and animal powered mills was known to Chinese and Muslim [[papermaking|papermakers]]. However, evidence for water-powered paper mills is elusive among both prior to the 11th century.<ref>Tsien, Tsuen-Hsuin 1985, pp. 68−73</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Lucas|2005|p=28, fn. 70}}</ref><ref name="Burns 1996, 414fa.">{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414f.}}: {{quote|It has also become universal to talk of paper "mills" (even of 400 such mills at [[Fes|Fez]]!), relating these to the hydraulic wonders of Islamic society in the east and west. All our evidence points to non-hydraulic hand production, however, at springs away from rivers which it could pollute.}}</ref><ref name="Thompson 1978, 169">{{harvnb|Thompson|1978|p=169}}: {{quote|European papermaking differed from its precursors in the mechanization of the process and in the application of water power. [[Jean Gimpel]], in ''The Medieval Machine'' (the English translation of ''La Revolution Industrielle du Moyen Age''), points out that the Chinese and Arabs used only human and animal force. Gimpel goes on to say : "This is convincing evidence of how technologically minded the Europeans of that era were. Paper had traveled nearly halfway around the world, but no culture or civilization on its route had tried to mechanize its manufacture."'}}</ref> The general absence of the use of water-powered paper mills in Muslim papermaking prior to the 11th century is suggested by the habit of Muslim authors at the time to call a production center not a "mill", but a "paper manufactory".<ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414f.}}: {{quote|Indeed, Muslim authors in general call any "paper manufactory" a ''wiraqah'' - not a "mill" (''tahun'')}}</ref>
Scholars have identified paper mills in [[Abbasid Dynasty|Abbasid]]-era [[Baghdad]] in 794–795. The evidence that waterpower was applied to papermaking at this time is a matter of scholarly debate.<ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|p=414}}:{{quote|Al-Hassan and Hill also use as evidence the statement by Robert Forbes in his multivolume Studies in Ancient Technology that "in the tenth century [AD] floating mills were found on the Tigris near Baghdad." Though such captive mills were known to the Romans and were used in 12th-century France, Forbes offers no citation or evidence for this unlikely application to very early papermaking. The most erudite authority on the topography of medieval Baghdad, George Makdisi, writes me that he has no recollection of such floating papermills or any papermills, which "I think I would have remembered."}}</ref> In the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] city of [[Fes|Fez]], [[Ibn Battuta]] speaks of "400 [[Millstone|mill stones]] for paper".<ref name="Tschudin 1996, 423"/> Since Ibn Battuta does not mention the use of water-power and such a number of water-mills would be grotesquely high, the passage is generally taken to refer to human or [[Horse mill|animal force]].<ref name="Burns 1996, 414fa."/><ref name="Tschudin 1996, 423">{{harvnb|Tschudin|1996|p=423}}</ref>
===Water-powered mills=== [[File:Veluwse Papiermolen, Openluchtmuseum Arnhem.jpg|thumb|Dutch paper mill from 1654 in the Arnhem open-air museum]] [[File:Nuremberg chronicles - Nuremberga.png|thumb|Stromer's paper mill, the building complex at the far right bottom, in the ''[[Nuremberg Chronicle]]'' of 1493. Due to their noise and smell, papermills were required by medieval law to be erected some distance from the city walls.]] An exhaustive survey of milling in [[Al-Andalus]] did not uncover water-powered paper mills, nor do the Spanish books of property distribution (''Repartimientos'') after the [[Reconquista|Christian reconquest]] refer to any.<ref name="Burns 1996, 414fb.">{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414f.}}</ref> Arabic texts never use the term mill in connection with papermaking and the most thorough account of Muslim papermaking at the time, the one by the [[Zirid dynasty|Zirid]] Sultan [[Al-Muizz ibn Badis]], describes the art purely in terms of a handcraft.<ref name="Burns 1996, 414fb."/> [[Donald Routledge Hill|Donald Hill]] has identified a possible reference to a water-powered paper mill in [[Samarkand]], in the 11th-century work of the Persian scholar [[Abu Rayhan Biruni]], but concludes that the passage is "too brief to enable us to say with certainty" that it refers to a water-powered paper mill.<ref>{{citation|title=A history of engineering in classical and medieval times|author=[[Donald Routledge Hill]]|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=1996|isbn=0-415-15291-7|pages=169–71}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414}}: {{quote|Donald Hill has found a reference in al-Biruni in the 11th century to stones "fixed to axles across running water, as in Samarkand with the pounding of flax for paper," a possible exception to the rule. Hill finds the notice "too brief to enable us to say with certainty" that this was a water-powered triphammer.}}</ref> This is seen by Leor Halevi as evidence of Samarkand first harnessing waterpower in the production of paper, but notes that it is not known if waterpower was applied to papermaking elsewhere across the Islamic world at the time.<ref>{{citation|title=Christian Impurity versus Economic Necessity: A Fifteenth-Century Fatwa on European Paper|author=Leor Halevi|journal=[[Speculum (journal)|Speculum]]|year=2008|volume=83|pages=917–945 [917–8]|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|doi= 10.1017/S0038713400017073}}</ref> Robert I. Burns remains sceptical, given the isolated occurrence of the reference and the prevalence of manual labour in Islamic papermaking elsewhere prior to the 13th century.<ref name="Burns 1996, 414−417"/>
Hill notes that paper mills appear in early Christian [[Catalonia|Catalan]] documentation from the 1150s, which may imply Islamic origins, but that hard evidence is lacking.<ref>{{citation|title=A history of engineering in classical and medieval times|author=[[Donald Routledge Hill]]|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=1996|isbn=0-415-15291-7|page=171}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=414f.}}: {{quote|[[Thomas F. Glick|Thomas Glick]] warily concludes that "it is assumed but not proved" that Islamic Xàtiva had hydraulic papermills, noting that the pertinent Arabic description was "a press." Since the "oldest" Catalan paper is physically the same as Islamic Xàtiva's, he notes, their techniques "can be presumed to have been identical" - reasonable enough for Catalan paper before 1280. My recent conversations with Glick indicate that he now inclines to non-hydraulic Andalusi papermaking.}}</ref> Burns, however, has dismissed the case for early Catalan water-powered paper mills, after re-examination of the evidence.<ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=415}}: {{quote|Currently Oriol Valls i Subin't, director of the History of Paper department of the Museos Municipales de Historia in the Instituto Municipal de Historia at Barcelona, has popularized a version of that thesis, in which Christian paper mills multiplied marvelously along the Catalan rivers "from Tarragona to the Pyrenees" from 1113 to 1244. His many articles and two books, valuable for such topics as fiber analysis in medieval paper, continue to spread this untenable and indeed bizarre thesis. As Josep Madurell i Marimon shows in detail, these were all in fact cloth fulling mills; textiles were then the basic mechanized industry of the Christian west.}}</ref> The identification of early hydraulic stamping mills in medieval documents from [[Fabriano]], Italy, is also completely without substance.<ref>{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=416}}: {{quote|Fabriano's claim rests on two charters - a gift of August 1276, and a sale of November 1278, to the new Benedictine congregation of Silvestrine monks at Montefano. In each, a woman recluse-hermit gives to the monastery her enclosure or "prison" - Latin ''carcer''; misread by Fabriano partisans as a form of Italian ''cartiera'' or paper mill! There is no papermaking in these documents, much less hydraulic mills.}}</ref>
Clear evidence of a water-powered paper mill dates to 1282 in the Spanish [[Kingdom of Aragon]].<ref name="Burns 1996, 417f.">{{harvnb|Burns|1996|pp=417f.}}</ref> A decree by the Christian king [[Peter III of Aragon|Peter III]] addresses the establishment of a royal "[[Watermill|molendinum]]", a proper hydraulic mill, in the paper manufacturing centre of [[Xàtiva]].<ref name="Burns 1996, 417f."/> This early hydraulic paper mill was operated by Muslim [[Mudéjar]] in the [[Moorish]] quarter of Xàtiva,<ref>{{cite book|title=Medieval Science, Technology, and Medicine: An Encyclopedia|author=[[Thomas F. Glick]]|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2014|page=385|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=77y2AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA385}}</ref> though it appears to have been resented by sections of the local Muslim papermakering community; the document guarantees them the right to continue the way of traditional papermaking by beating the pulp manually and grants them the right to be exempted from work in the new mill.<ref name="Burns 1996, 417f."/>
The first permanent paper mill north of the Alps was established in [[Nuremberg]] by [[Ulman Stromer]] in 1390; it is later depicted in the lavishly illustrated ''[[Nuremberg Chronicle]]''.<ref>{{harvnb|Stromer|1960}}</ref> From the mid-14th century onwards, European paper milling underwent a rapid improvement of many work processes.<ref>{{harvnb|Stromer|1993|p=1}}</ref>
The size of a paper mill prior to the use of industrial machines was described by counting the number of vats it had. Thus, a "one vat" paper mill had only one vatman, one coucher, and other laborers.<ref>{{citation|title=Papermaking, the History and Technology of an Ancient Craft|author=[[Dard Hunter]]|publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]]|year=1943}}</ref>
=== 20th century === By the early 20th century, paper mills sprang up around [[New England]] and the rest of the world, due to the high demand for paper. At this time, there were many world leaders of the production of paper; one such was the [[Brown Company]] in [[Berlin, New Hampshire]] run by William Wentworth Brown. During the year 1907, the Brown Company cut between 30 and 40 million acres of woodlands on their property,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MxILAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA70 |title= History of the lumber industry of America|accessdate=April 5, 2012}}</ref> which extended from [[La Tuque, Quebec|La Tuque]], [[Quebec province|Quebec]], Canada to [[West Palm, Florida|West Palm]], [[Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.berlinnh.gov/Pages/BerlinNH_WebDocs/BerlinHistory|title=About Berlin: Berlin History|accessdate=April 5, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109062959/http://www.berlinnh.gov/Pages/BerlinNH_WebDocs/BerlinHistory|archivedate=November 9, 2012|df=}}</ref>
In the 1920s [[Nancy Baker Tompkins]] represented large paper manufacturing companies, like Hammermill Paper Company, Honolulu Paper Company and Appleton Coated Paper Company to promote sales to the distributors of paper products. It was (said to be) the only business of its kind in the world and was started in 1931 by Tompkins and prospered in spite of the business depression. <ref>{{cite journal|title=Monday, July 9, 1934|journal=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=1934|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/274992413/?terms=%22Nancy%2BBaker%2BTompkins%22|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
“[[Log driver|Log drives]]” were conducted on local rivers to send the logs to the mills. By the late 20th and early 21st-century, paper mills began to close and the log drives became a dying craft.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.pprc.info/html/millclosures.htm|title=Paper Mill Closures of America|accessdate=April 5, 2012}}</ref> Due to the addition of new machinery, many millworkers were laid off and many of the historic paper mills closed.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://worldofdecay.blogspot.com/2010/10/lumber-town-berlin-new-hampshire.html|title=Urban Decay|accessdate=April 5, 2012}}</ref>
==Characteristics== {{Main|Pulp mill|Paper machine}} Paper mills can be fully integrated mills or nonintegrated mills. Integrated mills consist of a pulp mill and a paper mill on the same site. Such mills receive logs or wood chips and produce paper.
The modern paper mill uses large amounts of [[energy]], [[water]], and [[wood pulp]] in an efficient and complex series of processes, and control [[technology]] to produce a sheet of paper that can be used in diverse ways. Modern paper machines can be {{convert|500|ft}} in length, produce a sheet {{convert|400|in|m}} wide, and operate at speeds of more than {{convert|60|mph}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metsoautomation.com/News/newsdocuments.nsf/Web2NewsDoc/CAC7C79ED6B6E117C22572A00048448C?OpenDocument&ch=ChMetsoPaperWebEng&id=CAC7C79ED6B6E117C22572A00048448C&|title=Metso supplied SC paper machine line sets a new world speed record at Stora Enso Kvarnsveden|accessdate=2008-04-12}}</ref> The two main suppliers of paper machines are [[Metso]] and [[Voith]].
